Use preprocessor assertions to fail misconfigured builds.

cards.desc: Bonus points for autoconf help.
cards.name: Find some genius to teach me how to write Makefiles that don't suck.

cards.desc: This will be an ongoing card.
cards.name: Continual audit of Doxygen conformance.

cards.desc: This will be an ongoing card.
cards.name: Audit class scopes. Encapsulate.

cards.desc: mbedtls seems fairly well-organized. While not the smallest-possible library, it is probably the best choice for API compatibility where a full-featured cryptographic API might be required.
cards.name: Implement mbedTLS for the cryptographic library

cards.desc:
With the addition of persistent storage, this becomes a serious issue.

Make sure this behavior is well-defined, and flexible enough to adapt to the presence or absence of cryptography support, TPM, storage, etc...
cards.name: Define behavior surrounding "First Boot".

cards.desc: This will end up being a means of passing configuration at run-time without having to pre-script behaviors in callbacks (or similar tricks).
cards.name: Configuration API data struct

cards.desc:
The synchronous signalling system in BufferPipe should be made to carry a potential configuration payload.

This is necessary to allow pipe-strategy to run far-to-near.
cards.name: Implement the new config API in BufferPipe strategies.

cards.desc: This might be done using iotivity-constrained.
cards.name: OIC1.1 Support
XenoSession ought to store the counterparty message legend.
Make XenoSession reply to messages it did not initiate.
Make XenoSession enter a desync state when too many successive parse failures are seen.

cards.desc: The goal is to take a dynamic string (which must be pain-painstakingly compared) and reduce it down into an integer pointer which can be compared and indexed quickly.
cards.name: Write a string comparison to integer code translator.
Strip non-exportable types, message codes, and grammatical forms from the MessageLegend prior to sending it.

cards.desc: This should be a separate message. Most machine-clients will not care about semantic data, its presense on the wire will likely exceed the MTU of small devices, and not every firmware will support it.
cards.name: Add a message for the semantic legend.

cards.desc: nextTick is essential for breaking synchronous pathways without the overhead of the event system.
cards.name: Implement a nextTick() callback

cards.desc: ManuvrRunnable should be purged of some of the cruft from the scheduler. It should be handled with a less fragmented API.
cards.name: Give the scheduler's remains a final pass-over.

cards.desc:
Boot process must be well-documented.

Differences in boot process need to be explicitly addressed by firmware at run-time.

BOOT_COMPLETE should be continually recycled in the Runnable queue until no action is taken by any module. This process must be aborted if it runs too long.

In order for that to work, BootComplete() must be audited in all modules, and partially-rewritten in EventReceiver. Now would be a good time to think about allowing module trees.
cards.name: BOOT_COMPLETE specification.

cards.desc:
BufferPipe's signals presently take a void\*. Now that the Argument class has proven to be flexible enough, convert this to an Argument\*.

This will allow propagation of arbitrary configurations alongside pipe strategy.
cards.name: Formalize signals in BufferPipe

cards.desc:
Interpret this as a polling request from the Kernel. 

The class will have the chance to do things as it would in a threaded environment. This will be a nice segue into ER implementing it's own thread-management, as ManuvrXport sort-of does.
cards.name: Allow ER::notify() to take a null pointer.

cards.desc: Have an interface like JS emitter/listener relationship, whereby the LISTENER dictates what it wants directly, versus having to passively listen to the ENTIRE message flow. IE, "emtr.on(msg_code, fxn_pointer);"
cards.name: Rework EventReceiver to work more like JS emits.

cards.desc: The kernel ought to be able to more-directly manipulate the environment of a FreeRTOS build.
cards.name: Specific messages for task-management under FreeRTOS

cards.desc: If we are going to be running EventReceivers in their own tasks, we need to be able to call their notify() methods, and other associated control-points. The first step is to create a pair of FreeRTOS queues to move messages back-and-forth.
cards.name: Pass ManuvrMsg objects through an RTOS queue.

cards.desc:
Some EventReceivers know a priori that they will introduce heavy load, I/O, or concurrency risks with other ERs. Such tasks should be able to be delegated to specific FreeRTOS tasks.

This might be done via special coding of the ER itself.
Or via a Kernel faculty.
Or via an interface class that ER inherits.
cards.name: Allow EventReceivers to be fractioned off into tasks under FreeRTOS.

cards.desc: It would be *really* neat to be able to run many kernels within a single application (not necessarily firmware).
cards.name: Running parallel kernels

cards.desc: This will be essential to accomplishing the parallel kernel task, as well as being helpful for system daemon communication.
cards.name: Need an IPC transport for ManuvrMsgs

cards.desc: memcpy() is likely to take better advantage of ALU width when copying, thereby maximizing memory bandwidth.
cards.name: Convert all explicit copy loops into memcpy() calls.

cards.desc: Rework the crufty old SensorWrapper class to be more coherrent with the new features in ManuvrOS. This will involve making a new EventReceiver (SensorManager) and a new legend.
cards.name: Implement the sensor legend.

cards.desc:
We should have the capability of communicating GPIO props to a counter-party, as well as responding to writes/read/reconfig of those pins.

This will require new messages. Such a GPIO legend will only be required if the Manuvrable intends to share it's GPIO pins with counter-parties.
cards.name: Implement a GPIO legend in ManuvrOS.
Flesh out INA219 class. This will allow us to measure battery usage.

cards.desc:
The byzantine command-codes and integer sequences has finally fallen apart.

Implement a proper feature breakout that is dynamically invokable.
cards.name: Sane interface to console

cards.desc:
This will be touchy, because C-linkage is vital in some places. But where tolerable, it would be *really* nice to have the notion of platform extension tidier than it could ever be in straight-up C.

Finish an initial version of the Platform object.
cards.name: Objectify Platform encapsulation.

cards.desc: This encompasses all Teensy3.x variants.
cards.name: Teensy3

cards.desc: Do not put Raspi stuff here. The issues in this card should apply equally to *any* linux environment.
cards.name: Linux

cards.desc: Note that this is a linux platform. General-linux stuff is tracked under that card. This card is *only* for the Raspi. Typically this comes down to hardware support.
cards.name: Raspi

cards.desc: Note that this is a linux platform. General-linux stuff is tracked under that card. This card is *only* for the Raspi2. Typically this comes down to hardware support.
cards.name: Raspi2

cards.desc:
Do I really care... Probably not enough to move this card forward, except where it also applies to the other Arduino-esque platforms (chipKIT and Teensyduino).

If issues arise, and someone wants such-and-such a thing, I might put it here.
cards.name: Arduino

cards.desc: This is here mostly for historical reasons and drift-tracking. ManuvrOS was developed on this platform, but only Digitabulum r0 uses it. Unless some compelling reason can be given why specific issues and platform support should continue here, this card will remain dead.
cards.name: STM32F4

cards.desc: The concurrency risks associated with this flavor of platform are not fully understood. Abuse the platform and try to cause some bugs.
cards.name: Concurrency-hardening under FreeRTOS and multi-threaded conditions

cards.desc: Be able to translate between CBOR payloads and native map structures.
cards.name: CBOR support

cards.desc:
Storage is a new interface class.
Platforms will have a specific implementation of this capability. API TBD.

BufferPipes will be used to obtain handles on the data-stores by a name. Linux platforms will interpret this name as a filename, and will write each data-store as its own file, which will follow config-driven semantics for permissions.

Non-filesystem implementations (IE: 4KB EEPROM), might choose to interpret store names as keys in a CBOR map (or other similar data structure).
cards.name: Persistent storage in firmware

cards.desc:
To facilitate power-management, start using the return value from procIdleFlags() to inform choices about thread sleep/clock scaling.

Might be nice to have a Fibonacci decay curve for sleep time in threaded environments. The same could be done with a simple PMU interface.
cards.name: Add a KernelIdle idle callback.
XportXform class to do session discovery and instantiation

cards.desc:
Presently, DMA is implemented (at least partially) in all classes that deal with bus operations. There are 3 transport classes, 3 callback classes, and 3 job classes. Unify the common elements and extend them as a base class.

This is a low-priority task, as the SPI operations are likely to be unused in Digitabulum, where they will be subsumed into the CPLDDriver for performance reasons.
cards.name: Merge the classes involved in bus queues and transports into a single set of interfaces.
EventManager needs to be able to hold deferred events in a separate queue.
Condense ScheduleItem and ManuvrEvent into an abstract base-class: ManuvrRunnable.

cards.desc:
We don't need absolute precision on this platform. The fact is, most timers are long-running or one-shot affairs, and don't need to be 1ms resolution.

Make a linux user-space platform case-off to update the scheduler with a delta for time-passed, rather than simply incrementing a value and taking it as a given that the incrementation is tightly periodic.
cards.name: Timers on linux to drive the scheduler forward.
EventReceivers should register the messages that they use at boot.

cards.desc: This will allow a more flexible definition strategy, at a minor cost to runtime overhead.
cards.name: The messageDefs need to be stored in the event manager, rather than statically defined in the messaging layer.

cards.desc: These two things are so intimately connected that they ought to reside in the same object. This will save overhead on several fronts with no penalty for loss-of-generality.
cards.name: Condense EventManager and Scheduler into Kernel.

checkItem.name: Tie this to the First-Boot effort.

No EEPROM support. It would be slick to use it to back-up the conf persist API.

data.text:
Platform objectified. Many bytes saved. 32-bit build reports a base-class size of only 28 bytes.

Extension of the base class should be done in a different manner. So far, it builds for the STM32F7 and linux. Other platforms will be trivial, as this is a net complexity cut, and the features are already written in many places.

Making this task finer-grained, and keeping it open.

This goal was massively advanced this weekend. Presently, linux is the only implementation, and there is no clear serialization strategy. But the API looks like it will hold water.

Progress continues....
Internal data type defined. It is now a matter of adding specific features.

checkItem.name: Re-work class to use constant char* for keys.
Finish digesting and re-purposing ConfigItem from BridgeBox. Re-name class and make it compile.

card.name: Implement a nextTick() callback
card.desc: nextTick is essential for breaking synchronous pathways without the overhead of the event system.

card.name: Formalize signals in BufferPipe
card.desc:
BufferPipe's signals presently take a void\*. Now that the Argument class has proven to be flexible enough, convert this to an Argument\*.

This will allow propagation of arbitrary configurations alongside pipe strategy.

data.text: This was advanced last week. Translation functions are not yet complete, but cpp-cbor builds and is usable from within the firmware. Simple integers are packable.

card.name: CBOR support
card.desc: Be able to translate between CBOR payloads and native map structures.

data.text: No fancy Fibonacci curve. Just a simple successive idle counter that, once depleted, causes an idle-hook call.

I have decided to do this as a set of fxn pointers in the platform object. The particulars of the strategy will change and be expanded, but it appears to meet all the requirements.

User firmware can clobber the default pointers at runtime, optionally saving them first, and calling them manually in their own functions (if desired).

card.name: Define behavior surrounding "First Boot".
card.desc:
With the addition of persistent storage, this becomes a serious issue.

Make sure this behavior is well-defined, and flexible enough to adapt to the presence or absence of cryptography support, TPM, storage, etc...

card.name: BOOT_COMPLETE specification.
card.desc:
Boot process must be well-documented.

Differences in boot process need to be explicitly addressed by firmware at run-time.

BOOT_COMPLETE should be continually recycled in the Runnable queue until no action is taken by any module. This process must be aborted if it runs too long.

In order for that to work, BootComplete() must be audited in all modules, and partially-rewritten in EventReceiver. Now would be a good time to think about allowing module trees.

data.text:
This has been partially accomplished. The EventReceiver class now exists and works on basically every platform that supports GPIO, thanks to the hard-won battle of platform-abstracting GPIO.

The messages have been defined, but there has not yet been a need of them.

Dropping this task's priority for now....
The RN-42 driver has been ported over. It doesn't work yet.

data.text: This has been done to the extent practical. Without re-inventing an elemental set of interface to abstract hardware-specific features, the BusQueue and work items have been unified. Further abstraction is not planned until it is required.

data.text:
Linux build is fairly-resilient. I haven't seen concurrency-related bugs in many months. Ditto for FreeRTOS, but I don't use it as much.
Keeping this card open until more formal review is conducted.

Condense EventManager and Scheduler into Kernel.
card.desc: These two things are so intimately connected that they ought to reside in the same object. This will save overhead on several fronts with no penalty for loss-of-generality.

card.name: Condense EventManager and Scheduler into Kernel.

card.desc: This will allow a more flexible definition strategy, at a minor cost to runtime overhead.

EventManager needs to be able to hold deferred events in a separate queue.

Add a message for the semantic legend.
Implement the sensor legend.
card.desc: Rework the crufty old SensorWrapper class to be more coherrent with the new features in ManuvrOS. This will involve making a new EventReceiver (SensorManager) and a new legend.

card.name: Implement a GPIO legend in ManuvrOS.
card.desc:
We should have the capability of communicating GPIO props to a counter-party, as well as responding to writes/read/reconfig of those pins.

This will require new messages. Such a GPIO legend will only be required if the Manuvrable intends to share it's GPIO pins with counter-parties.

card.name: Implement a GPIO legend in ManuvrOS.
Condense ScheduleItem and ManuvrEvent into an abstract base-class: ManuvrRunnable.

data.text: This will allow lots of code re-use, more mobile events, and (ultimately) safer programmers, due to higher comprehensibility.

card.name: Condense ScheduleItem and ManuvrEvent into an abstract base-class: ManuvrRunnable.

data.text: Until this is done, the glove will not be able to handshake by spec.

checkItems.name: Make hardware connect and speak reliably.
Library should extend ManuvrTransport to leverage common events and XenoSession i/f,
Be able to conditionally add and remove those listeners at runtime.
Add a series of methods to allow EventReceivers to discover what other EventReceivers are broadcasting into their kernel.
Dispatch a ManuvrMsg to another running task.
Cause a running task to delete itself.
Spawn a task and fraction off long-running or I/O messages into it.
Get true ISR behavior on Teensy3
Bus operation structure is doing too much. Makes portability a nightmare. Shovel platform-specific support into i2c-driver.

Stop coding i2c with the assumption that only one such ER exists in the system. Need to be able to support a few. Add a parameter to I2C_QUEUE_READY message to denote the bus, or do so by some other means. Also, re-work the volatile extern I2CAdapter reference.
Builds are enormous. This might have been a chipKIT issue that has been solved. I noticed their group discussing fixes related to this symptom.
i2c relies on the cruddy Arduino API. Find something comparable to the t3_i2c library.
No anything. Write things to do stuff with the transistors.

Introduced many gaps and bugs surrounding essentially all HAL drivers. ST changed their API, and I never brought the STM32F4 case-offs up-to-spec. There isn't even a Platform.cpp file this build any more.
It would be cool to have SPI or PWM support. But nothing depends on it yet.
It would be cool to have SPI or PWM support. But nothing depends on it yet.
No EEPROM support. It would be slick to use it to back-up the conf persist API.
Verify that the NeoPixel driver still works.
No scheduler, because: no timer. Fix.
No FreeRTOS. We have full-blown threads and a memory-management unit with oodles of memory attached to it. Use them.
Conf-Persistence API should be using files or SQLLite. We have disk to burn in this platform.

checklists.name: Tests that need to be written

Use the str->const str fxn to do key lookup and comparisons.
Finish an initial version of the Platform object.
Wrap thread creation into Kernel. Not platform.
Use the Raspi as a use-case for extension of platform. (Raspi extends linux)
Integrate it with Platform object effort.
Do we really want to bring BufferPipe into this? It kinda makes sense, but might be a nightmare.
